author: Charlotte Cox
title: Driver accused of killing two young cousins in crash admits failing to stop - but denies dangerous driving
text:
Helina Kotlarova and Zaneta Krokova (Photo: PA) Share Get daily   man accused of killing two young cousins in a horror crash in Oldham on New Year’s Eve has admitted being behind the wheel of the car - but denies causing their death by dangerous driving. 
Gabor Hegedus, 38, appeared before a judge at Manchester Minshull Street Crown Court faced with six charges including causing the deaths of Helina Kotlarova, 12, and Zaneta Krokova, 11, on New Year’s Eve. 
Wearing a grey tracksuit and with a Hungarian interpreter by his side, Hegedus admitted being the driver of a Peugeot 807 which failed to stop after it was involved in an accident with Helina Kotlarova and Zaneta Krokova and failing to report an accident. 
He also admitted driving without a licence and perverting the cause of justice by agreeing to dispose of the vehicle and making a false report of theft to the police. 
However he pleaded not guilty to causing the deaths of Helina, 11, and Zaneta, 12, by driving a Peugeot 807 dangerously along Ashton Road, Oldham on December 31. Read More Dangerous armed robber who escaped prison by climbing over a wall is back behind bars Gabor Hegedus 
Three fellow defendants, David Orsos, 18, Janos Kalanyos, 50, and Zoltan Peto, 49, also appeared in the dock wearing tracksuits and flanked by interpreters. 
Charged with perverting the cause of justice, Orsos pleaded not guilty to agreeing to dispose of a vehicle and falsely reporting an accident, while no pleas were submitted by the other two men. 
More than 15 family members of the two girls killed in the New Year’s Eve crash were present in court. 
Throughout the hearing, a man among them interpreted what was said to relatives. 
As the four men left the dock to be returned to the cells, the family of the girls who lost their lives in the New Year’s Eve crash shouted at the defendants, who cast their eyes down as they were led away by security officers. Read More 
Judge John Potter told the defendants that a date for trial had been set for June 26, as well as for an earlier hearing on March 31. 
Adjourning the case, Judge Potter addressed family members of the two girls directly. 
He said: “Thank you for coming and thank you for conducting yourself for the most part in an appropriate manner during the most part of the hearing. 
“I do appreciate that it’s a difficult case for most of you.” Like us on Facebook
